metadata.work_product: 5.5.1 – Item definition resulting from requirements in 5.4

1_introduction.title: 1. Introduction
1_introduction.prompt: State the purpose of this document: to define the '{system_name}' as the 'Item' per ISO 26262-3:2018. Specify its role in the vehicle system architecture and its relevance to functional safety. Do not include background, history, or general statements. Focus only on scope and safety context.

2_1_legal_requirements.title: 2.1 Legal Requirements, National and International Standards
2_1_legal_requirements.prompt: List only the legal, national, and international standards that directly apply to the '{system_name}'. For each, specify its relevance to functional safety (e.g., 'UNECE R100: mandates electrical safety during charging'). Avoid generic lists; include only standards that impose safety-related constraints on this item.

2_2_functional_behaviour.title: 2.2 Functional Behaviour at Vehicle Level
2_2_functional_behaviour.prompt: Describe the '{system_name}' behaviour in each operational mode (e.g., Standby, Active, Fault, Maintenance). For each mode, specify: (1) triggering conditions, (2) primary functions performed, (3) outputs produced, and (4) transition conditions to other modes. Use precise technical language; avoid subjective terms like 'monitors' or 'handles'.

2_3_performance_requirements.title: 2.3 Required Quality, Performance, and Availability
2_3_performance_requirements.prompt: Specify quantitative performance requirements relevant to safety. Include: accuracy (±X units), response time (≤Y ms), availability (≥Z%), and reliability (MTBF > W hours). For each, state the safety rationale (e.g., 'Response time ≤10ms ensures safe shutdown before thermal runaway').

2_4_constraints.title: 2.4 Constraints Regarding the Item
2_4_constraints.prompt: List all constraints affecting the '{system_name}': (1) environmental (temp, humidity, EMC), (2) functional (dependencies on sensors, networks, power), and (3) resource (CPU, memory, power budget). For each, state the assumed operating range and the consequence of violation.

2_5_consequences_of_shortfalls.title: 2.5 Potential Consequences of Behavioural Shortfalls
2_5_consequences_of_shortfalls.prompt: For each critical function of the '{system_name}', describe the hazardous event that would result from its failure or malfunction. Specify the potential harm (e.g., 'loss of braking control → collision') and the affected parties (driver, passengers, pedestrians). Link each to a potential safety goal.

2_6_actuator_capabilities.title: 2.6 Capabilities of the Actuators (or Assumed Capabilities)
2_6_actuator_capabilities.prompt: Quantify the actuation capabilities of the '{system_name}': (1) maximum response time for safety actions (e.g., 'contactor opens in ≤30ms'), (2) force/torque/current limits, and (3) diagnostic coverage of actuators. These values must support HARA controllability and severity assessments.

3_boundary_and_interfaces.title: 3. Boundary of the Item, Interfaces, and Interaction Assumptions

3_1_elements_of_item.title: 3.1 Elements of the Item
3_1_elements_of_item.prompt: List all hardware and software elements within the scope of the '{system_name}'. For hardware: ECU, sensors, actuators. For software: modules, drivers, libraries. Explicitly state what is excluded (e.g., 'Battery cells are out of scope').

3_2_assumptions_on_vehicle_effects.title: 3.2 Assumptions Concerning Effects on the Vehicle
3_2_assumptions_on_vehicle_effects.prompt: State assumptions about the vehicle’s response to the '{system_name}' outputs. Examples: 'Driver will react to warning within 2s', 'Vehicle can coast to stop if propulsion is lost', 'Other ECUs will respect safety states'. Assumptions must be verifiable and realistic.

3_3_functionality_required_by_others.title: 3.3 Functionality Required by Other Items
3_3_functionality_required_by_others.prompt: List functions or data the '{system_name}' provides to other systems. For each, specify: (1) recipient system, (2) data/function provided, (3) update rate, and (4) safety relevance (e.g., 'SoC to VCU: used for torque control').

3_4_dependencies_on_other_items.title: 3.4 Functionality of Other Items Required by This Item
3_4_dependencies_on_other_items.prompt: List functions or data the '{system_name}' requires from other systems. For each, specify: (1) source system, (2) data/function required, (3) timing dependency, and (4) failure consequence (e.g., 'Loss of VCU mode signal → safe state activation').

3_5_function_allocation.title: 3.5 Allocation and Distribution of Functions
3_5_function_allocation.prompt: Describe how safety-critical functions are allocated between hardware and software within the '{system_name}', and across external systems if applicable. Use a table if needed. Specify which entity is responsible for each function (e.g., 'SoC estimation: BMS software').

3_6_operational_scenarios.title: 3.6 Operational Scenarios Impacting Functionality
3_6_operational_scenarios.prompt: List realistic operational scenarios that challenge the '{system_name}' safety (e.g., 'Fast charging at -20°C', 'Collision during highway driving'). For each, describe: (1) scenario conditions, (2) expected item behaviour, and (3) safety mechanisms activated.

4_conclusion.title: 4. Conclusion
4_conclusion.prompt: Confirm that this document satisfies ISO 26262-3:2018 Clause 5.4. State that it provides sufficient detail to proceed to HARA (Clause 6) and Functional Safety Concept (Clause 7). Do not add new information; only affirm completeness and compliance.

5_approvals.title: 5. Approvals
5_approvals.prompt: Insert a table with columns: Role, Name, Signature, Date. Rows: Safety Engineer, System Architect, Project Manager. Do not fill values; leave as placeholders.
